dt: {bc}a specific sequence of {d_link|nucleotides|nucleotide} in {d_link|DNA|DNA} or {d_link|RNA|RNA} that is located usually on a {d_link|chromosome|chromosome} and that is the functional unit of inheritance controlling the transmission and expression of one or more traits by specifying the structure of a particular {d_link|polypeptide|polypeptide} and especially a protein or controlling the function of other genetic material

shortdef: a specific sequence of nucleotides in DNA or RNA that is located usually on a chromosome and that is the functional unit of inheritance controlling the transmission and expression of one or more traits by specifying the structure of a particular polypeptide and especially a protein or controlling the function of other genetic material

et: French {it}-gène{/it}, from Greek {it}-genēs{/it} born; akin to Greek {it}genos{/it} birth

dt: {bc}a genetic process that involves nonreciprocal meiotic recombination in heterozygotes in which a mismatched DNA sequence from one heteroduplex DNA strand is replaced with a sequence complementary to the other strand resulting in aberrant gametic ratios (such as 3:1) and that is observed especially in ascomycetous fungi

shortdef: a genetic process that involves nonreciprocal meiotic recombination in heterozygotes in which a mismatched DNA sequence from one heteroduplex DNA strand is replaced with a sequence complementary to the other strand resulting in aberrant gametic ratios (such as 3:1) and that is observed especially in ascomycetous fungi

dt: {bc}the use of biotechnological techniques to make changes to specific DNA sequences in the genome of a living organism

dt.t: Fundamental research into the ways by which bacteria defend themselves against viruses has recently led to the development of powerful new techniques that make it possible to perform {wi}gene editing{/wi}—that is, precisely altering genetic sequences—in living cells, including those of humans, at much higher accuracy and efficiency than ever before possible.
The era of straightforward {wi}genome editing{/wi} raises ethical questions that will need to be addressed by scientists and society at large.

aq.auth: Jennifer A. Doudna and Emmanuelle Charpentier

dt: often hyphenated when used before another noun

shortdef: the use of biotechnological techniques to make changes to specific DNA sequences in the genome of a living organism —often hyphenated when used before another noun

dt: {bc}the passage and establishment of genes typical of one breeding population into the gene pool of another

shortdef: the passage and establishment of genes typical of one breeding population into the gene pool of another

dt: {bc}the ratio of the number of a specified allele in a population to the total of all alleles at its genetic locus

shortdef: the ratio of the number of a specified allele in a population to the total of all alleles at its genetic locus

dt: {bc}a permanent alteration (as by {d_link|point mutation|point mutation} or {d_link|frameshift|frameshift} mutation) in the nucleotide sequence of a gene

dt.t: Researchers have identified a {wi}gene mutation{/wi} that's believed to predispose people to malignant melanoma, the deadliest and most aggressive type of skin cancer.

shortdef: a permanent alteration (as by point mutation or frameshift mutation) in the nucleotide sequence of a gene

dt: {bc}the collection of genes in an interbreeding population that includes each gene at a certain frequency in relation to its alleles {bc}the genetic information of a population of interbreeding organisms

shortdef: the collection of genes in an interbreeding population that includes each gene at a certain frequency in relation to its alleles : the genetic information of a population of interbreeding organisms
the process of preparing recombinant DNA

dt: {bc}the insertion of usually genetically altered genes into cells especially to replace defective genes in the treatment of genetic disorders or to provide a specialized disease-fighting function

shortdef: the insertion of usually genetically altered genes into cells especially to replace defective genes in the treatment of genetic disorders or to provide a specialized disease-fighting function
